articles.title: J&J regrets paying for study that injected incarcerated Black men with asbestos — report - Endpoints News
articles.description: Newly unsealed court documents reveal that Johnson & Johnson paid for a study that injected 10 incarcerated Black men with asbestos, as part of the company's early talcum powder trials, according to a new report in Bloomberg News. While news of the 50-year-ol…
